conclusion: Need to apply Snell's Law and understand the geometry of the Dawes prism.
The Dawes prism is an isosceles right-angle prism with angles at C and D being 45° each.
The light ray enters the prism through edge AC, inclined at 45° to the base CD.
Apply Snell's Law at the entry point AC: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2).
n1 = 1 (air), theta1 = 45° (angle of incidence), n2 = sqrt(2) (refractive index of the prism).
Calculate sin(theta2) = (1 * sin(45°)) / sqrt(2) = 1/2, therefore theta2 = sin^(-1)(1/2) = 30°.
Determine if the light can exit through CD by considering the critical angle for total internal reflection.
Critical angle theta_c for the prism is sin^(-1)(1/sqrt(2)) = 45°.
Since the light is traveling at 30° with respect to the normal, it is less than the critical angle of 45°, meaning it will not undergo total internal reflection at CD.
Conclusion: Refraction angle when the light enters the Dawes prism is 30°, and the light can exit through edge CD.
Final Answer: Refraction angle when entering the prism: 30°. The light can exit through edge CD.
